reviewText:
Don't Starve is a wilderness survival game.  You are left in a world to explore, set up camp, and above everything else... Don't Starve!   Here's my review as a disabled gamer (I play with only a mouse).

http://youtu.be/ODVOMhXkags

Don't Starve begins in Full Screen but you can immediately access options to change to windowed mode.  Windowed mode is borderless so you can access your desktop without exiting the game.  No colorblind settings were in the options.  Mouse only gamers can play with ease.  When you start this game you may not see your friends or family for weeks...  the game is just that good!  Everything can be controlled with simple mouse clicks, a few keyboard buttons can help you lower your right clicking and adjust camera settings.  You can left click to move your character collect objects or attack.  For keyboard only gamers the news isn't as good.  You can walk using wasd & collect items with space.  My problem came when trying to access build menus.  I personally never found a key to access them and looking through forum posts I failed to find a solution.  If keybindings do become available,  I'll definitely update notes here!

reviewText:
Long Story ShortDon’t Starve is an extremely difficult masterpiece that will take you 50+ hours in order to learn how to survive in this unforgiving universe. The art style is unique and the sounds/music is beautiful and creepy.  The game play is outstanding and it will, whether you want it to or not, draw you in for hours of game time without giving you a chance to take a break. You’ll probably starve in real life before you can but your controller down. It’s without a doubt a 10/10 and is one of the few games I think couldn’t even be improved upon.

Long Story Long- The Game PlayDon’t Starve is a survival game and therefore your only natural objective is to survive. This is accomplished by keeping your sanity, hunger, heath, warmth, and sogginess in check. In order to do so, you’ll gather resources, make your camp, plant crops, craft recipes, etc. in order to create a working outpost. The game will constantly become more difficult as Maxwell, the villain, sends his hounds to attack you, you run out of any resource, and then there is the ever looming threat of winter.

Variations to the game playThis game is almost 100% customizable whether you want more or less tall birds, no winter, or if you want to commit suicide by making it permanently night time.  There are also several unlockable characters that all have different stats, starting items, and uses. Lastly, you can, if you’re lucky enough to find a rare portal, switch to adventure mode where you are plopped in a premade world, opposed to the randomly generated worlds in survival mode, where you attempt to live past the more difficult worlds you’re put into in order to make it to the next and, eventually, toss Maxwell off his throne of lies!

Music and SoundThe creators of Don’t Starve cut no corners when it comes to the music and sound effects. The music is beautiful, exiting, and darn right creepy depending on the circumstances. In fact, me and my roommate once did a scientific experiment in order to see if playing frightening music, in this case music from Don’t Starve, at night while we were asleep would affect our dreams or not. We both had nightmares. The sound is also perfect for whatever action is happening. I often want to eat my food reserve just so I can hear Wilson munching away at the meat or kill a spider so I can hear it shriek.

ArtThe art style for Don’t Starve is completely original and shows character for objects through its harsh strokes or gentile lines. Combined with the music and sound, the art gives the player a perfect atmosphere that, in my opinion, has never been matched by another survival game.

DLC and Don’t Starve TogetherThe DLC for Don’t Starve, Reign of Giants, adds craftibles, items, enemies, and even two whole freaking seasons! If you ask me, this DLC adds difficulty and challenge to this already challenging game and, unless you’ve played lots of survival games, I wouldn’t suggest using it till you’ve at least made it till winter in the normal version. As far as Don’t Starve Together goes, it adds a little content as well as making the game significantly easier. I’d suggest you’d get it if you’ve already bought and liked the original but find yourself wanting to shake things up by tossing in some other players.

ConclusionGame play- 10/10. Music and sound- 10/10. Customizability - 10/10. Art style- 10/10. DLC- 10/10. This is the best survival game I’ve ever played or ever seen played.  It’s addicting, entertaining, and challenging. Without a doubt it’s on my top ten favorite game list. It’s also one of four games I think is as flawless as humanly possible.  Oh course, like all games, there is those who won’t enjoy it. So if you’re a female of the age 30+ or just someone who doesn’t normally enjoy intense, extremely difficult games, the most likely won’t find Don’t Starve appealing. However, to anyone that doesn’t fall in those categories I’ll say this: Don’t Starve is a chef-d'oeuvre, a masterpiece beyond words, perfected in every way, and I can’t suggest it enough. Final rating- 100/100 one of the few perfect games on this earth.

reviewText: A very challenging and fun game, Don't Starve brings us the creativity of Minecraft and the adventure of Terraria and mash them together with some lovely art. You play *mainly* as Wilson, a scientist who was whisked away into this hellish world of violent trees, annoying hellhounds, and a deadly night. Although this game is quite challenging, and yes, frustrating, it is a lot of fun to play and experience for yourself. There are gameplay mechanics such as sanity, hunger, and weather. As you see more disturbing things, your sanity drops, making shadows and other hallucinations appear at night, and eventually, at day. Hunger is, obviously, a big problem. As you go throughout your day with food in your inventory, it will decompose and spoil. To combat this, you either eat it or store it in an ice box. Even so, your food still isn't completely safe in the ice box. Finally, there is rain, lightning, snow, and more snow. As the winter months draw near, you will be forced to stay near your fire unless you have the proper attire. Each and every enemy in this game is basically out for your head as well. The hellhounds will come every once in a while to remind you to stay on guard. Swamps come alive with deadly spiked tentacles that lash out if you get too close. Pigmen will defend their brethren to the death if need be. All of this comes with a grim reminder that to survive, you must always be alert, unless you want a beefalo horn shoved up your bum. 9/10 overall score

reviewText: Don't Starve is a 2013 action-adventure video game with survival and roguelike elements, developed and published by the Canadian indie company Klei Entertainment. The game was initially released via Valve's Steam software for Microsoft Windows, OS X, and Linux on April 23, 2013. A PlayStation 4 port became available the following year and further versions for iOS and mobile phones are under consideration. Downloadable content titled Reign of Giants was released on April 30, 2014, and a multiplayer expansion called Don't Starve Together became free for existing users on June 3, 2015.[1]\n\nThe game follows a scientist named Wilson who finds himself in a dark, dreary world and must survive as long as possible. Toward this end, the player must keep Wilson healthy, fed, and mentally stable as he avoids a variety of surreal and supernatural enemies that will try to kill and devour him. The game's Adventure" mode adds depth to the sparse plot and pits Wilson against the game's antagonist
recommended: you unlock more valuable and specific-abilities characters.'\n\nRate: 11/10"

reviewText: This game really turned me against myself. A part of me really liked the game, while another was eagerly waiting to get off. Dont Starve is a survival game that blends a unique style of artwork with a fasinating story. By all means, the story is very well done and the gameplay is not bad, and if you like survival this is the game for you, but somewhere it just failed. It failed when it came to replay value, or how much you can play a game after you have finished it once. i felt that it started getting repetetive, doing the same things over and over for the same objective. Overall, i do recommend this game to anyone who loves survival, but i would only buy it if it were on sale.

reviewText: If you don't have this game in your library yet. You have to get it. It's an amazing sandbox and survival game with Tim Burton-esque art style. You'll never get the same world twice, and the adventure mode is really challenging. If someone tells you that they already did everything in Don't Starve and have less than 10 hours, they're lying, there's TONS of stuff to do, Get through winter, fight bosses, explore the caves and the ancient ruins, and if you get bored, assemble the Wooden Thing and change characters in a new world to make it a much challenging or different experience. The devs are amazing and keep the game fresh. Currently waiting for the Fall DLC. They also try to respond to all e-mails personally as well as comments on their Facebook page. Also since the addition of workshop you can improve your game and have a lot more things to do. I love this game and every aspect of it. 10/10

reviewText:
This game is addicting.

The style of the game in my opinion fits this scenario and the humor behind it is clever.

The game offers you countless hours of fun and plenty of stuff to do around.One thing I love about it is the fact that once you're dead..you're dead.This makes you stay in constant fear of losing all of the progress and this fear only intensifies with the progress you make.

Again,the number of things you can do are almost countless.You can set a whole forest on fire just because you want to or because you want to kill something that is after you!You can explore caves and fight bats and spiders or just build yourself a small town from which you can sustain yourself without exploring.You can choose to be a explorer and wander from one place to another to try and discover new creatures and new resources.

The replay ability of this game is insane due to the fact that the game has tons of good mods and that the devs put so much work into releasing a lot of free updates.Also the game randomly generates the world,that means you will never have the same experience twice.

reviewText: Jeeeeeeesuuussssssssssssss, I just love this game. When I first booted it up, I was perfectly normal about it. I didn't think much of it in the game menu, but immediately when I spawned in my first world, a man appeared and said I have to prepare food and shelter before dark, I am on my own, and he drops me off in the middle of nowhere. Right when I saw him, I cracked a jolly smile. The man was tall, in a suit, holding a briefcase, and with dark brown hair. Sound familiar? Yes. Very. What? Dafuq? Not familiar? Well, let me give you a hint. GMAAANNNNN. Yea, NOW, does it sound familiar? required resources are randomly scattered along the terrian, and different biomes containing many useful resources. The great thing about these resources, is just so cool. Picked up something useless? Not possible. Everything has it's own purpose. I just love that. When The day turns to night, EVERYTHING GOES BLACK. Im not kidding you, EVERYTHING goes black. And you get hit by... something... And you die in a matter of seconds. This, of course, can be avoided by building a torch or a campfire, which are very cheap items. There are so many good things about this game, if I listed all of them, this review would be 45 paragraphs long, so I'm just gonna stop writing here. I highly recommend this game and if you have a spare 15 bucks, buy it. Immediately. Or I'll eat you. Well, anyways thanks for reading, goodbye!

reviewText:
A while back I reviewed this as boring, basic and lacking. And it was. I played during the first days of release, and didn't give it enough time to get interesting. After sinking a ton of hours into this and still finding new things to want to check out, mess around with, explore and unlock, it's safe to say Don't Starve is a well made and interesting game.

It's stacked with charm and intrigue. It still has a dead end in terms of discovery, tech and gameplay, like any survival or city sim game, but it's going to take you a lot longer to get there in Don't Starve than most other games. It's also fuelled by lots of strange little gameplay mechanics and items that you find along the way.

I haven't even touched the DLC yet, and I'm not the greatest fan of survival games, but Don't Starve has definitely given me my moneys worth after investing a little time and effort.

Pretty boring survival game. Don't Starve starts off with the same feeling you get playing Minecraft for the first time: You want to collect food and items to survive the first night and it's pretty exciting and fun.

Unfortunately this is about it, and after the first few days of experimenting and finding out what everything does all you're left with is exploring and fighting. Fighting never really seems very exciting and has no real purpose other than maybe collecting items, and exploring seems like a waste of time since it doesn't help you survive any longer (which ultimately is the goal of the game). As a result this game gets boring very quickly and there doesn't appear to be much to do.

Pretty boring survival game.

reviewText: YES! YES! Another Minecraft themed game, not first person, not 3D but that's what makes this game unique, Almost as good as Minecraft if not better. In this game, you are given a character (you unlock characters later) and you need to survive for as long as you can, picking up resources that will aid in getting you a weapon or Light Sources and helping you in battle. There are lots of food for you to pick up which in my opinion was limited in Minecraft. This game also gives you access to Mods so you can download Mods from the steam workshop which i find helpful especially the mods that have a neverending light source. I am loving this game. This game lets you save your progress, Food is much easier to find than in Minecraft. Some of the features are better than Minecraft already. This is a 2D Minecraft! Simple as that. I definitely recommend you buy this game because it has come to the point where every Steam user MUST have a copy of this game.\n\n10/10 Fricking Awesome

reviewText:
The game really revolves around collecting basic ingredients and crafting them into survival gear/items. You are going to want to collect food RIGHT away, you will get hungry fast. You are going to want to cook this food with fire. You are also going to want to build tools like axes, pickaxes, etc and harvest quite a bit of raw materials. Then you are going to want to build science machines in order to build better tools/survival gear/weapons.

Combat is fairly basic, click and run is the general tactic. I really think this is a wiki friendly game despite spoilers. You should learn about what items you want and how to craft them by searching a wiki.

This is really a fun game.  The Devs have released a ton of content and fixes since then and continue to update once a month or so. And the good part is if you have a low - end pc you can run it though with the netbook modus.

reviewText:
If you often lament about you as a player having low control over high-level events in a game or over the game environnement, this is the game for you.
Don't Starve is a survival game and a nice sandbox: go explore, gather stuff and make the best possible use of ressources by combining them in one way or another.
The artistic direction is endearing (think of Tim Burton works, for instance) and comes with some welcome sense of humor much needed in that cruel game world - you will die again and again.

Last but not least, the developper support on this game deserves praise, there have been tons of very valuable updates to the game.

reviewText:
Welcome to a game where every single thing absolutely, positively, bloody, freaking hates you.

When you first play, you probably won't get to Day 2. But then when you play again, it gets slightly better, cuz you'll be smart enough to build a fire. Then, you might start complaining about how there's a lack of stuff to build, and you won't make it far with basic tools. Then on your third gameplay, you come across a gold nugget. Lucky you, it's time to build a science machine. Then you start testing and making all sorts of funky stuff, thinking you're invincible until you cut way too many trees. Heh, no ruining surprises here, but just remember to keep a few acorns handy for planting. Nonetheless, you probably die out of inexperience. Then you'll start your fourth gameplay and forget about your sanity. Welp. So goes your fifth, six, seventh. Guess what? You're hooked.

11 out of 10 for ruining my life and making me see terrorbeaks when I wake up to go to the toilet at night. #thisgamereallyfrickinhatesyou

reviewText:
This is the best survival game I have ever played. If you love survival, you are not doing yourself any favors by avoiding this game. It throws you to the wolves and does not hold your hand.

Yes, the graphics are cartoony, but dont be fooled. This game will test your skills and you will die and die and die again. Grab the DLC's and you have a beast of a challenge to survive. Especially the new Shipwrecked DLC.

I have owned this game for years and still keep coming back.

The mechanics are deceptively simple, pick up as much stuff as you can and start trying to figure out how to survive. Not starving is only one priority. You will want to set up a camp and start doing science to unlock the best stuff. You will also have weather and heat and cold to contend with on top of the fact that nearly everything will try and kill you in one way or another.

Caves add another layer of challange to the game with multiple levels of darkness and monsters to explore. You cook, build, explore, fight, and science the ♥♥♥♥ out of things to try and survive.

Use Wiki or Youtube to help get started.

Overall this game is one of my favorite all time games. Do yourself a favor and buy it now if you dont own it.

reviewText:
In its minimal and simple atmosphere, Don't Starve succeeded where many failed: delivering a balanced, challenging and story driven survival game.

As the obvious main focus is to survive (and how hard it can be at the beginning!), the player will progress through a story that has an impact in the game (trying to avoid any potential spoilers).

The survival machanism is traditional and unique at the same time:
There are many resources to loot, and several items can have multiple uses (for example pine cones can be planted, used as fuel to feed the fire or become crafting material); exploring the land around you not only gets you to secret or story-related areas, but also signals how the world changes due to nature rhythm (for example seasons will progress and according to them resources may grow again faster or slowlier, the day/night cycle will change), moreover, it is always best NOT to explore during the night: the land becomes completely dark, pitch dark, and creatures will literally devour you unless you have a source of light, so it's best to build a safe place and dedicate the night to crafting and refining materials you gathered in the day.
Crafting and researching new technologies" is
recommended: the vital part of the game. You start with some basic knowledge of craftable items
hoursPlayed: but you need to build scientific buildings (and stand next to them) to unlock more advanced options.\n\nThe grotesque atmosphere is one of the winning points of this game: everything is weird and questionable
voteText: from totem-adoring pigs to crawling shadows. The overall feeling of Don't Starve is similar to when you read a fantasy book
helpfulPercent: curled up in your bed sheet as a thunder storm is raging from afar.\n\nIf you love survival games
votesHelpful: dark settings and challenging stories
votesTotal: get this game!"
votesFunny: November 16, 2015

reviewText: This game is HARD.  You get thrown into it with no tutorial, no explanation and no help.  Not gonna lie - I ended up looking a lot of things up at the beginning because I don't deal with these types of games very well.  However, you learn quickly and it gets to the point where you don't care why you're in this other world, why there are shadow creatures trying to kill you, etc.  You just have to survive.\n\nThere's a lot of item collection and the opportunity to build bigger and better defenses, offenses, etc. There's no real right or wrong way to play this game.  You will probably die a lot but there is tons of replayability.

reviewText:
I've been playing games since I was 8 years old. I'm 21 now and I can tell you that this is one of the best games I have played in my entire life.

With that said, I want to tell you why this game is so good.

1st and most important of all is; this is a survival game. Meaning hard difficulty and permanent death. Even though, you can customize the world to your liking and survive with your conditions. The default version being the intended difficulty.

2nd is the gameplay. You can move with clicking your mouse, just like in any Diablo-esque games. You can move with ASDW (which I prefer and recommend). It's simple to play and is very responsive. The game is simple in graphics and has really good animations (meaning anyone can play it!). The music and sounds are awesome but they might become repetitive at some point (at which you just turn them off :D). This may be one downside that bothered me a bit, but it is not a big problem at all.

3rd is the game itself, you are placed inside a world where you are only told that you should look for something to eat. Don't starve is not nearly the only danger you should look out for. You have to stay warm in the Winter, stay cool in the Summer, protect your things, avoid monsters, kill monsters, survive giants, maintain sanity. But more importantly, you build structures, walls, farms, protective structures, traps, weapons, tools. Furthermore, you explore secrets, caves, biomes, animals, monsters, items! There are so many options in this game to explore. I have 40-ish hours on this game (for now) and I have only explored barely half of all the things that can be done. I haven't even customized the starting world yet! I've been playing default untill I got the hang of it. But the number of settings and customizations you can make to your world are nearly endless! You can also unlock other characters which all have different perks and abillities.

4th and last are the community mods that can expand and improve your game greatly (I'm using 8 mods at the moment). Not to mention the upcoming multiplayer that will allow you and your friends to experience this survival game in a world that has your rules and settings.

I highly recommend this game to anyone that likes: survival / fighting / building and crafting stuff.

Best regards, Devon.

recommended:

The one thing that really makes this game a treasure is the simplicity. What? You might ask. I will try to explain:
The UI/ menus are perfectly uncomplex. They are neat
hoursPlayed: responsive and incredibly easy to navigate as everything is very well organized.\nThe inventory spaces are placed neatly at the bottom of the screen and are always available to you. you have the option of organizing your materials into a few groups with slight spaces between lots of inventory slots. reviewText:
It really is one of the best indie games ever made. You can play it for as long as you want, because you can unlock more characters with their own personalities and possiblities. The good things about this game are:
- A random world generator - You will never play on the same map again! Yes. NEVER.
- You can customize your world - YOU pick if you want frogs, trees, rabbit holes, long day, long night, short winter, etc.
- New characters to unlock - They have their own possibilities and personalities.
- The game has got a sense of humor and nice graphics
- It isn't really expensive and worth the money

Negative things:
- The game can get too stressful - If you build a big house with a fireplace, stone walls, science machine etc. and if you die... Well, you can get very disapointed.
- Literally everything can kill you in this game - Even frogs!
- After some time of playing you will simply get bored - But hey, you can always generate a new map!

So yeah, Don't Starve is a very nice indie game. If you're a fan of such games - It's a must-have for you!

reviewText:
Spawned in a new world to try to unlock some of the characters to try them out.
After seeing Maxwell nag me about finding food I go North in a leisurely fashion with a tired expression on my face.
I find what  looks to be a neat wooden fortress with skeleton bones and a chest right at the entrance.
I open the chest and there's a Fire Staff" that I briefly see before I hear a burning sound.
I catch on fire and run away as my protagonist says "Oops" as the once neat looking fortress is burning and I am left in awe at what just happened in the matter of my first minute of playing on this new world. I then died the next day to a Killer Bee.

This game is genuine. 10/10."

Don’t Starve raises the bar on “survival games”, while many games hold your hand, or let you have an easier game mode, Don’t Starve is actually the opposite, when I start to lose in don’t starve, I feel the game kicking me while I’m down.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5ivaQrjjYmQ

date: you don't look so good. You better find something to eat before night comes!" Those are words to live by. I haven’t actually finished the story myself

reviewText:
This game's art style is really what caught my eye in the first place, so I thought I would buy it whenever it went on sale.

Basically this is a game of survival and there are many things that can kill you. Your character is thrown into a world of vast wilderness and left to fend for himself/herself. Each world is randomly arranged and have random spawnings, keeping the game pretty fresh and new. You gather natural materials like sticks and rocks, make tools like axes and shovels, make traps or weapons to catch animals for food, set up campfires for survival, etc.
In the game you have three things you want to keep in check when surviving: Health, Hunger, and Sanity. If you lose your health, well, you can die. If you lose your hunger, you lose your health and die. If you lose your sanity, you start seeing things. Eventually your hallucinations become violent when you're insane and can hurt you. You can also unlock different and unique characters depending on in-game events or accomplishments.

The art style of this game in my opinion, is very unique and eye-catching. The game is very smooth and doesn't lag alot in general. (depending on how your computer is running though.) It does crash sometimes though. (I've had it crash twice on me.) I have also found a few glitches in the game (before Reign of Giants.)

This game gives you alot of chores for survival to keep you occupied, though sometimes it does get repeative. The worlds in Maxwell's Gate are the true challenges, whether its going through endless winters or rain. Or even hunted by hounds. Every world is filled with multiple monsters and critters to kill or survive from. There are also tons of material to collect for tons of creations you can unlock and survive with, giving this game some variety if you get that far. I really love the different characters in this game too, each one having their own charms and personalities. (My favorite character is Webber.) At times I get alot of creepy vibes from this game, especially at night when my sanity is getting low. And accomplished vibes whenever I survive from stuff.

This game does have its charms, but it also has its fair share of flaws. Some of the flaws with this game is the repetiveness when trying to survive multiple times. Dying is definitely a big disappointment, especially when you get pretty far. This was not meant to be a very easy game though. The farther you get, the harder it gets. I would also say that some of the music (mostly in reign of giants) is a little too...cheesy, in a way? (I suppose its meant to be like that but still,) And some of the character's voices (which are instrument sounds) get a little annoying at times. Like Wilson's, for example, and when he gets hurt. The things they say give them alot of personality though. Especially Wendy. One more thing, sometimes (especially when you're a newbie) you encounter things that you have no idea how to deal with unless you look it up. (Which I suggest doing research before eating any of those colorful mushrooms unless you want to do it yourself.)

One last thing I have to say about this game is this: It's not for everyone. Some people (like me) will really like this game, and others might think its as boring as heck, everyone has their own tastes. So, if you're interested in it, I suggest checking this game out and maybe watch other people play it. Its a very fun game and can get time-consuming, I'd say its worth a buy. 8/10.

Another thing: Multiplayer is comming soon! :D

reviewText:
Spawned in a new world to try to unlock some of the characters to try them out.
After seeing Maxwell nag me about finding food I go North in a leisurely fashion with a tired expression on my face.
I find what  looks to be a neat wooden fortress with skeleton bones and a chest right at the entrance.
I open the chest and there's a Fire Staff" that I briefly see before I hear a burning sound.
I catch on fire and run away as my protagonist says "Oops" as the once neat looking fortress is burning and I am left in awe at what just happened in the matter of my first minute of playing on this new world. I then died the next day to a Killer Bee.

This game is genuine. 10/10."

reviewText:
It really is one of the best indie games ever made. You can play it for as long as you want, because you can unlock more characters with their own personalities and possiblities. The good things about this game are:
- A random world generator - You will never play on the same map again! Yes. NEVER.
- You can customize your world - YOU pick if you want frogs, trees, rabbit holes, long day, long night, short winter, etc.
- New characters to unlock - They have their own possibilities and personalities.
- The game has got a sense of humor and nice graphics
- It isn't really expensive and worth the money

Negative things:
- The game can get too stressful - If you build a big house with a fireplace, stone walls, science machine etc. and if you die... Well, you can get very disapointed.
- Literally everything can kill you in this game - Even frogs!
- After some time of playing you will simply get bored - But hey, you can always generate a new map!

So yeah, Don't Starve is a very nice indie game. If you're a fan of such games - It's a must-have for you!

reviewText:
We are all familiar with the stereotypical grunting, primitive, idiotic caveman. But have you ever tried going outside (bear with me, we're all gamers here) and trying to make a simple tool with only rocks and sticks? Given the fact that they were born into a world where it was kill or be killed and every day was a fight for survival, it's incredible what the cavemen managed to accomplish.

In Don't Starve, you take control of a scientist named Wilson*, who has just been thrown into a world as deadly as those the cavemen lived in. However, you have the advantage of knowledge. You know what fire is and how to make it. But you better make it quickly, because the night is fast approaching, and unlike the cavemen, your stars and moon do not provide light. At least, not enough to keep the shadows away.

Welcome to a world of survival, where terrors lurk around every corner, where hunger and madness can prove more dangerous than wild beasts, where death is always a few steps behind. Can you gather the resources you need to defy your own doom? Can you build, research, and advance, all while keeping hunger and madness at bay? Can you build a civilization to stand the test of time? Oh wait, wrong game. Anyway, the world of Don't Starve is filled with horrors and dangers. And that's not even including the winter.

Oh, yes. Winter. The most dangerous time of year. Perhaps you thought you were safe from starvation with your bountiful crops of fruit and vegetables. But when the ground freezes over, the plants become stagnate. Now, right when you thought you were safe and secure, you find yourself on the brink of disaster again. For winter is the season of the hunt. But what are you? The hunter? Or the prey? Brace yourself. Winter is coming.

Wait, wrong thing again. In any case, this game is a must-have for those who love surviving by the skin of their teeth. The art style is reminiscent of Tim Burton animated movies, making the game truly unique in its field. The gameplay is great, either with keyboard and mouse or with the steam controller. At the time of writing this review, I've played 70 hours of Don't Starve, and I've only scratched the surface. Maybe that's just because I suck at it, but even so I enjoy it immensely. And I haven't even gotten started on the DLC's yet!

*Wilson is the default character, but there are many others, including Willow the Firestarter, Wolfgang the Strongman, and Woody the... well, you'll see. ;-)

reviewText:
Don't Starve: Shipwrecked  is a standalone expansion to the base survival game  Don't Starve . Let it be known that I have not played the original game to any extent and my impressions are based on the expansion and its content.

Narrative  The narrative is entirely freeform and allows the player to create their own story according to personal playstyle. Your enjoyment in this regard is mostly limited to your own imagination. However, each playable character has his or her own personality quirks, quips and unique gameplay interactions. For example, my favorite character is a snotty librarian who is able to bypass certain tech restrictions due to her vast intelligence and in exchange is unwilling to eat spoiled food.

Gameplay  Due to the nature of permadeath games, the player's response to death is paramount to whether or not the game succeeds. When the player inevitably sees the You died" screen
date: frustration will be a natural response. However
recommended: does the player feel enticed to try again? Has the player learned valuable information that will serve to prevent the same death from occurring?  Don't Starve: Shipwrecked  succeeds for the most part in this regard. For example
hoursPlayed: at a predetermined time a certain mob will spawn and attack the player. This acts as a test to see if the player has adequately prepared. The first time I had to fight this mob

votesTotal: while congratulating myself with a hearty vegetable stew
votesFunny: I was punched to mincemeat by a enraged ent revenging his fallen children who I had unwittingly used as my kindling for said stew. And so the ouroboric cycle of punishment/information/success/punishment continued. During the downtime when you are not being chased by rabid sharks or angry buffalo

Watch their monkey huts burn down; watch the baby monkeys scream for mercy while you lounge by the shore sipping some iced tea and listening to Rage Against the Machine.\n\nSensory  The art style looks like the baby of The Legend of Zelda: The Wind Waker and American McGee's Alice: sharp lines and bright
column20: contrasting colors all wrapped up in a twisted design. You will never look so good being mutilated over and over again. The sounds are interesting

column23: the musical soundtrack needed more variance - I eventually listened to my own music and was perfectly content.\n\nConclusion  Do you enjoy being slapped in the face repeatedly by someone other than your wife? Do you relish the idea of convincing monkeys to murder each other with their own feces? Are you titillated by the notion of spending five hours building an empire only to die from a coconut falling on your head?  Do you enjoy complex games with a myriad of gameplay elements which allow you to play your own game against the game? If you said yes to the above then  Don't Starve: Shipwrecked  is a game definitely worth dying."

reviewText:
:dsham:

Isometric view survival game with quite unique, memorable art style.

As you may imagine from the title, focus here is on non-combat survival - fighting hunger and adverse environmental conditions like weather or darkness at night. Granted, monsters are out there to get you as well.

The game is rather open ended, no clear goals other than survival, although there's an adventure mode to find, which is a more focused challenge.

You're definitely meant to discover things yourself on the go, through many deaths of you, forging mad in-game survival skills in fires of hell. If you're looking through guides, wikias, videos... you are somewhat missing the point and missing out great deal on the intended fun".

And good riddance

reviewText:
Let me start this review by telling you how I absolutely LOVE this game. Do note that this review contains spoilers and stuff that might ruin parts of discovery and fun in the game
I cannot put my love for this game in words but I will try to explain some points of why I believe this is the revolutionary game that help video games progress as form of art.
--------------------------------------
First of all let me start by telling about the social commentaty this game makes.
I know it's hard to see the social commentary in a game where you're all alone in the wilderness but it's there to be found. The social commentary is subtle and told in a very dark soul-ish way which is leaving hints and bits of information that the player figures out.
There are multiple parts implying that the silent protagonist is a female-to-male transgender. For example the protagonist has very feminine jaw and chin. He also has feminine hair with lots of volume.
Another not so noticed part is the depression in his eyes. Many think the depression is from being alone in the wilderness and darkness of the world. Well they're wrong. It is from the depression caused by being transgender and being oppressed by white cis men and women.
---------------------------------
Now to the story of the game. I know this is hard to believe for most people, even the most diehard fans of the game, but the game doesnt actually happen in wilderness but inside the person's dreams. The story is very metaphorical about everything. The safety of fire means support of loved ones when transitioning to opposite gender. The angry animals of the wilderness represent the people who are against his transitioning into a man. The neutral animals/critters are considered bypassers. Those are the people he is able to interact without the people being rude/different towards him just for being transgender.
The day and night cycle represent the mood swing caused by hormones in transition. While this is not social commentary, it tells about how reality reflects to his dream which the game is. This mechanism is one of the subtle things that make this game a masterpiece.
------------------------------
We're done with the story now, lets progress to the gameplay.
The gameplay is something completely fresh. You start of in a hostile world of no comfort, like transgender person is before getting his/her support for transitioning. Slowly you start gathering materials to get fire. The materials represent bits of trust you build up with other people. Fire represents, like I earlier explained, the support. This is a big gameplay aspect that makes this game extremely good.
Another excellent game mechanic is the hunger mechanic. Hunger reflects upon the character's need for love. If he is let without love, he will most likely die. In the dream he isnt just likely to die if the hunger for love isnt fed, he will die.
-------------------------------
I know this might be shocking to even most diehard fans but everything in this review was researched for a very long time. I spent countless hours finding out all of this and much more. I didnt include everything I found out in this review because I wanted to keep this as a Steam review and not a full review for a bigger site. If you're hungry for more information and stuff I've found out, just ask me.
This concludes my review and I strongly recommend everyone to play this.
If you're big fan of art games, this is a must have.

reviewText:
Personal Rating: 9/10

Yeah, that's how good it is. When it comes to gaming I hate most games, I didn't like Saints Row 4, Payday 2, Call of Duty and I'm sorry to say that I didn't like Dota 2 all that much, just haven't had the time to sit down and play that game.

But, on with the review at hand. Don't Starve. I got this game for £4.07 which is an absolute BARGAIN in my opinion. This game is truly amazing and it's in my top 15 games of all time.

Playing this game made me realise a few things. Firstly, this game is beautiful. I can't find anything wrong with this game. The art style, beautiful, the music, fantastic, the characters, extraordinarily made, designed and animated.

This isn't a review, this is a praise report, I love this game as I'm a HUGE fan of survival games and I put my hands down when I say this is the BEST SURVIVAL GAME I HAVE EVER PLAYED.

reviewText:
First time playing, makes it to day 22 and is doing quite nicely.
Already activated a touchstone and I have a camp set up for the night.
Lets get some spare wood.
Gets the wood and hears thundering footprints as a giant pine ent (level 3 treeguard) walks into the campfire light.
O.o wtf is that.
Dies.
Respawns at the touchstone only to get killed by a herd of mating beefalo.
Takes a moment to soak in that I just got 4 levels in 1 go.
Starts a new round with Wolfgang.

No lie, this game is beautiful.

reviewText:
A great survival game with many hours sunk into it.  I'm not too fond of the giants DLC however -- while it adds many nice new features, I find it makes the game much too heavy on it's 'perma death' genre.  Chances are, you will lose your sanity and die before you're able to explore many parts of the game.

I recommend starting by customizing your map settings...disabling the giants and perhaps even lowering the rate at which your sanity lowers.  Unless ofcourse, you're the gamer who enjoys dying over and over again...then the default settings should be ideal for you.

I still enjoy this game and find myself comming back...there's also a decent mod community in steam's workshop.

reviewText:
Don't Starve is an indie game about...not starving. Or getting killed by spiders. Or werepigs. Or stupid, randomly spawning dogs...or, well, there's a lot of ways to die in this game besides just starving, and I'll leave it at that. Overall, it's a rewarding, if not incredibly challenging, experience.

Usually, indie games are highlighted by either their story, design or gameplay, which may prove significantly more innovative or intriguing than your average AAA game. That's why we buy them. Don't Starve is...a little bit different, to say the least, in that it's not all that inspiring in terms of story or gameplay. Here's the story: you don't want to starve, and also there's this dapper looking gentleman who appears to be channeling the ghost of a douchy harmonium. In terms of gameplay, point-and-click or use WASD to move around and interact with your environment, etc, etc. It's nothing that special.

BUT! The design and presentation of the game make up for this apparent lack and reveal that the game itself is not nearly as lacking as it may seem to the wandering eyes of you potential buyers. In terms of design, its quirky, dark, funny and heavily Tim Burton-ized. The art style is simple enough that it doesn't overstep the abilities of its indie designers but still appears fresh, pretty and new, and each character you unlock through surviving longer and longer is unique, with his or her own set of perks and weaknesses that can be amusing, annoying or just plain scary. There's a girl who's dead twin literally follows her around, or a lumberjack with a possessed axe and a dark, beaver-based secret. Personally, I hope for more characters to be added to the vanilla game or perhaps as DLC because the current roster gets unlocked pretty quickly on an good three or four runs through the game. Still, these characters are more interesting than what you'll pick up from most games at this price.

And when you do delve deep into this game after many, many, many trial runs, you'll discover that there's actually a lot of lore and story to this world. This mostly begins after entering Adventure Mode (and if you die in this mode, it doesn't affect your progress in the sandbox world), which can be done by opening a door randomly generated in any of your played worlds. You progress through five unique and challenging worlds, and along the way, you get a chance to see some of this lore and will probably hunger for more. Don't Starve leaves a lot more questions unanswered than I would like, but it's all to the cruelly addicting benefit of the game itself.

Finally, I should address the difficulty of this game. You probably won't make it past the first five or so days on your first try without customizing the world. It's not an easy game, lacks any form of tutorial at all and all enemies, from bosses to weak spiders, can be found in the overworld on Day 1. Yes, there are one-time respawn points if you find them, but if you die, then it's over. Sometimes those respawn points don't even spawn. Your forty days of surviving through the turmoil of winter? Screw it! Never happened! And that does kind of suck, but it all adds to the tension and atmosphere of the game itself. You don't get a tutorial in the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ woods! No one saves you when you decide to attack a herd of water buffalo with a stick of meat! And that mushroom over there? What does it do? Oh wait, it drains all of your sanity and makes shadow creatures in your head eat off your face. That'll learn ya.

So yes, Don't Starve is difficult, especially during the winter months. But this is a survival game about surviving in a magical survival forest full of pop culture references and musical instruments. It's not supposed to be easy. And I'll tell you, there's nothing more rewarding than making it past your longest survival time. And if it's too hard, then you can tweak the spawning in a customized world so that only friendly bunnies and happy flowers populate your world. And occasionally, Satanic trees possessed with the vengeance of a thousand sundered splinters will pop up and absolutely wreck everything you hold dear and precious, as was intended by the Founding Fathers.

reviewText:
If anything there is to say about Don't Starve is that it's probably the best survival game out there at this moment. Besides having a very interesting art style and a great sense of humor, there is a large amount of things to craft and the resource gathering sates the kleptomaniac in me. All those grass and twigs you spent the past 30 min picking up? Yea you're going to need them. Unlike games such as Fallout where you can kind of just pick up things you want and avoid small drops, you're going to want to get everything you can. Nothing you find in the game is worthless, every drop and resource has a purpose which is a nice touch. There is an extensive wiki on this game, so if you need to know the use of a certain item or a crock pot recipe it's all available to you.

I have to say a few things. One is that if you're dumb like me and didn't know that charcoal is burnt wood, let that be an indication of how to get it (Crock Pot is one of the most important items to survive well past winter). Two is that you might want to get the mod that shows your status (in numerical value) and shows the value for food. It may make the game less frustrating while not taking away from it. Third is that this is a game with perma-death (although there are multiple ways to revive yourself) and dying is the only way to earn experience to unlock most of the characters.

Either way as you can tell I've sunk a large chunk of my time into this game and I highly recommend it.

reviewText: Tim Burton meets Gathering / Crafting adventure game goodness.\nThis game captures my imagination like very few others. What it lacks in immersion it makes up for in truckloads of creativity and art originality.\nSome of the mechanics feel a little left by the wayside" such as combat
date: which to me has always seemed to work a little haphazzardly. But the exploration and curiosity factor are so over the top its very easy to forget such things might get in your way.\nThe music and sound fit perfectly with the art style in a melancholy yet purposeful romp through a dark and twisted wonderland of putrid or warped settings.\nI've had a blast playing Don't Starve
recommended: on and off Steam. Don't let my Steam playtime fool you
hoursPlayed: I'm a long standing supporter of Don't Starve and highly recommend it to anyone with a penchant for slightly warped or morbid yet humorous adventures."

reviewText: This game's nice. Full of bloody surprises and you will be dying, again and again, then you finally learn how to play, set up a camp, harvest vegetables and create yourself a fluffly warm hat made of bunnies. You will mind your own business and avoid all the evil monsters. Maybe even invent stuff with your newly built science machine. SO HAPPY! Then a group of pinguins appears and you out of all the happiness can't resist to pet them. They instantly kill you in return. I didn't even visit places like worm holes and caves, the world is just too cruel. It's fun, just a little disappointing when you loose all your efford so easily. I like that you can modify the world to decrease the amount of evil in it and increase the number of carrots, before you start the game. Still, this one's a nerve kicker, I give it 7/10

reviewText: Definitely one of the best strategy/survival games that you can get. The rogue-like gameplay is challenging but your brushes with death will leave you with a feeling of satisfaction that many other games fail to deliver. The games style is like something taken right from a Jhonen Vasquez comic. The rich gothic theme is mesmerizing and make playing the game for hours on end easy. The environments and creatures never fail to make you smile. This game is a beautiful take on the survival genre and everyone should play it.

reviewText: Many survival games are a play it and you're done experience of the been there, done that quality. Not this one. Literally every playthrough is a new experience. Randomized land and creature spawn means one play may be much easier or much harder than the next, depending on what you get. Will you have enough lumber? Will there be enough prey? Too many spiders? Will you camp and be attacked by hounds your first night? Will you even find enough stuff to make a fire your second night?! And of course, if you're having too much trouble with something, you can customize the world and turn that creature off for a playthrough, OR you can up the chances of encounter to test your skills if it's getting boring. This combined with the colorful character options (every one has a personality that determines what they think of everything, and some are downright hillarious), means this game neve rgets dull or tiresome. I always find my way back to try my hand at lasting a bit longer. So far I'm up to 9 nights. My hint? Never camp near a pig village. No matter how tempting. Full moons just -suck-, The mods available through the community are amazing as well and I very much recomend a look through of those also!

Yeah, that's how good it is. When it comes to gaming I hate most games, I didn't like Saints Row 4, Payday 2, Call of Duty and I'm sorry to say that I didn't like Dota 2 all that much, just haven't had the time to sit down and play that game.

But, on with the review at hand. Don't Starve. I got this game for £4.07 which is an absolute BARGAIN in my opinion. This game is truly amazing and it's in my top 15 games of all time.

Playing this game made me realise a few things. Firstly, this game is beautiful. I can't find anything wrong with this game. The art style, beautiful, the music, fantastic, the characters, extraordinarily made, designed and animated.

This isn't a review, this is a praise report, I love this game as I'm a HUGE fan of survival games and I put my hands down when I say this is the BEST SURVIVAL GAME I HAVE EVER PLAYED.

reviewText:
Don't Starve is an indie game about...not starving. Or getting killed by spiders. Or werepigs. Or stupid, randomly spawning dogs...or, well, there's a lot of ways to die in this game besides just starving, and I'll leave it at that. Overall, it's a rewarding, if not incredibly challenging, experience.

Usually, indie games are highlighted by either their story, design or gameplay, which may prove significantly more innovative or intriguing than your average AAA game. That's why we buy them. Don't Starve is...a little bit different, to say the least, in that it's not all that inspiring in terms of story or gameplay. Here's the story: you don't want to starve, and also there's this dapper looking gentleman who appears to be channeling the ghost of a douchy harmonium. In terms of gameplay, point-and-click or use WASD to move around and interact with your environment, etc, etc. It's nothing that special.

BUT! The design and presentation of the game make up for this apparent lack and reveal that the game itself is not nearly as lacking as it may seem to the wandering eyes of you potential buyers. In terms of design, its quirky, dark, funny and heavily Tim Burton-ized. The art style is simple enough that it doesn't overstep the abilities of its indie designers but still appears fresh, pretty and new, and each character you unlock through surviving longer and longer is unique, with his or her own set of perks and weaknesses that can be amusing, annoying or just plain scary. There's a girl who's dead twin literally follows her around, or a lumberjack with a possessed axe and a dark, beaver-based secret. Personally, I hope for more characters to be added to the vanilla game or perhaps as DLC because the current roster gets unlocked pretty quickly on an good three or four runs through the game. Still, these characters are more interesting than what you'll pick up from most games at this price.

And when you do delve deep into this game after many, many, many trial runs, you'll discover that there's actually a lot of lore and story to this world. This mostly begins after entering Adventure Mode (and if you die in this mode, it doesn't affect your progress in the sandbox world), which can be done by opening a door randomly generated in any of your played worlds. You progress through five unique and challenging worlds, and along the way, you get a chance to see some of this lore and will probably hunger for more. Don't Starve leaves a lot more questions unanswered than I would like, but it's all to the cruelly addicting benefit of the game itself.

Finally, I should address the difficulty of this game. You probably won't make it past the first five or so days on your first try without customizing the world. It's not an easy game, lacks any form of tutorial at all and all enemies, from bosses to weak spiders, can be found in the overworld on Day 1. Yes, there are one-time respawn points if you find them, but if you die, then it's over. Sometimes those respawn points don't even spawn. Your forty days of surviving through the turmoil of winter? Screw it! Never happened! And that does kind of suck, but it all adds to the tension and atmosphere of the game itself. You don't get a tutorial in the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ woods! No one saves you when you decide to attack a herd of water buffalo with a stick of meat! And that mushroom over there? What does it do? Oh wait, it drains all of your sanity and makes shadow creatures in your head eat off your face. That'll learn ya.

So yes, Don't Starve is difficult, especially during the winter months. But this is a survival game about surviving in a magical survival forest full of pop culture references and musical instruments. It's not supposed to be easy. And I'll tell you, there's nothing more rewarding than making it past your longest survival time. And if it's too hard, then you can tweak the spawning in a customized world so that only friendly bunnies and happy flowers populate your world. And occasionally, Satanic trees possessed with the vengeance of a thousand sundered splinters will pop up and absolutely wreck everything you hold dear and precious, as was intended by the Founding Fathers.

reviewText:
Don't Starve

Pros: Great time killer, cute animation style, deep crafting and survival system, always a new experience with plenty of replayability.

Cons: Difficult to grasp at first, must learn from previous mistakes to improve, at times can feel slow.

I enjoy Don't Starve a lot and it is really fun to try and 1 up your previous attempt(s) and live for just a little longer. Although the game will constantly surprise you with somthing new that kills you, that is all part of the fun. Trying not to starve is usually the least of your worries here.

reviewText:
Review written after purchasing the DLC

About the Basic Game:

Alright lets get it straight and simple: the basic game is an extremly hard, easily modable and overall fun survival game. Interesting mechanics, good combat mechanics, and in general no items are completly useless. Even if you allow your food to rot because you do not have a fridge yet to slow spoilage down it will still have a use as fertilizer. Every damn item has a use in this game and that happens not that often. No item is outperformed by another one. Each of them have flaws. Even inferior" stone/flint which break more easily have a nice advantage over gold tools: They are alot cheaper to craft. Though the concept of gold tools is kinda stereotypic because gold is a really soft material... oh well. Oh and btw
date: you dont want to be in the darkness without a light.\n\nCreative and unique enemies with relativly decent movement patterns which will hit hard if you do not respect them as a propper enemy (though the regular spiders are a bit weak)
recommended: fairly expensiv but powerfull ranged weapons
hoursPlayed: a good
voteText: well balanced armor system and very lovely characters to play with. You can even play as the main antagonist "Maxwell" if you finish the game. Each character has its own unique abilities giving him perks to support his survival in some way and having disadvantages making certain things harder. For instance Wilson: That character is unlocked from the beginning. He has very well balanced stats and as a special perk he grows a beard. Doesnt sound that special right? But the beard can be shaved and used as an effigy of himself in order to give him another try in case he dies. And extra lifes are EXTREMLY HARD to obtain in the game. Other characters like Woodie
helpfulPercent: a canadian lumberjack
votesHelpful: has a fear of birds and therefor looses sanity near them
votesTotal: but brings his own unbreakable axe
votesFunny: a HUGE advantage over other characters. Also he is "cursed" which affects him at certain days (not spoiling too much).\n\nSo after hinting on sanitiy theres also a very inspiring sanity/insanity system. Surviving in a lone
commentsCount: strange world with different laws of physics can be harsh. Where everything you encounter might kill you you might turn insane. Well thats the case in the game: You slowly loose your sanity if certain events are happening. For instance if you are in the dusk
column16: exposed to certain terrifying hostiles or if you are close to some "evil flowers" which are poisoning the air arround them letting you go insane slowly. As sanity drops the character begins to hear weird noises
column17: voices and starts hallucinating draining his sanity further. Once he is over a certain threshhold those "hallucinations" manifest and you have to fight extremly powerfull
column18: otherworldly monsters who could have come from Lovecraft himself. Those "shadows" are able to teleport and as already said hard to kill. You have to gain sanity by doing "sane" things
column19: like picking a few dozens of flowers
column20: then throwing them away (well however that should keep you sane)
column21: wearing civilized clothes or killing said shadows. You need to be insane once in a while in order to survive alot better because said shadows drop a very usefull material.\n\nLastly I like to point out the weather/season system: In the standard game without the DLC there are 2 seasons: Summer and Winter. Summer is relativly easy
column25: survive. Winter turns the game alot harder. You will start freezing without a fire or propper clothing
column26:
have trouble finding food (good luck farming in winter) and a giant mob called deerclops will spawn at some point who has to be killed in order to protect your camp and your hard work. Winter plays completly different then the regular seasons.

And theres alot more content to explore then those highlights I listed up + the community really produces high quality mods for the game.


So now to the DLC:

I hate DLCs... usually. But if its that well done and for a price of 4.99$ then I can just say "Go ahead buy it now".
It adds the remaining 2 seasons and turns summer into a drought. In spring you have to fight with dampness of your character because of frequent rain. Summer is a drought which means plants will wither and dont yield food
column27: heat will affect you badly similar to winters cold
column32: you etc will combust once in a while if its burnable and faster food spoilage will occur. Autumn is by far the most peacefull season... untill you encounter the Giant in autumn which is extremly hard to fight. He is basicly a far stronger version then winters deerclops and has a "beserk attack" where he (or it) will rush towards you destroying any contraptions you build and derooting trees. He will eat any food he can find if left alone and only turns hostile if you hinder him from eating. Thats just 1 giant. There is 1 giant for each season now
column33: and the deerclops for winter got rebalanced and got a powerfull "icicle erruption" as a stomp attack causing icy spears to appear infront of him out of the ground.\n\nWith all the new seasons
column34: new giants/bosses and new survival mechanics... basicly all the content comes a heck of more items. Again all of them have uses and none of them are completly useless. And all of them are very balanced. Overall a very good "DLC" which I would rather call an addon because of the sheer mass of content it dumbs on you. Oh and you get to play 2 new unique
column36: characters with unique abilities. No reskins or anything like the stuff you get from bigger "AAA" companies or corrupted pieces of... (EA). This DLC worths the money and is a great addition to the main game.\n\nI highly recomment getting both
column39: joyfull yet extremly hard game. If you fail and die you lost everything if you dont have any kinds of resurrection methods. Its the thrill of loosing anything which makes the game really fun. And there are alot of mods out there
column41: some which add completly new "levels" to play as. Or just unique characters like a Weavile
column42: The red Soldier (Jane Doe) from TF2
column43:
The Heavy from TF2 or completly original characters with unique abilities (William J. Dannigar (hopefully I wrote that name right).

So go get the game if you want a challenge. Its fun and really enjoyable.

-Sigma

Before I forgot: For those guys (and girls) who are into tentacles. Guess whats in the game. Yes Tentacles. In damp swamps. Which will try to impale you with their damp
column45: hot spike on their tip. The tentacles are purple.\n\nAnd in the underground/caves are even BIGGER tentacles. If you touch them they will summon a good ammount of smaller tentacles out of the ground which will then impale you with their sharp spikes aswell. reviewText:
Wandered far from my house on the second day of winter, my thermal rock gave out, I lost half my health, but made a fire to hunker to. Got cocky and tried to get back to my home, and then froze to death. All for some gold.

Pros:
Replayability: This game almost makes you want to hit retry, and if you find yourself bored, download some mods.
DLC: Reign of giants is a DLC that changes how you play your game, adding 2 seasons, and a handful of new mobs to farm, kill, or be killed by.
Roguelike: This makes the game exciting, if you were to respawn constantly It would detract from the difficulty of the game(IMO)


Cons:
Minor bugs that screw with my control settings

Overall I give this game no rating because ratings suck. Buy the game if you like roguelike games. Please don't get it if you have the intentions to play something similar to minecraft.

Webber is the best...

reviewText:
Frustrating, and yet a great game to play! You got 1 life, and thats it! Don't starve is a very fitting name for this game, hunger will be one of your greatest opponents, but sanity comes in great as a second! At night, when the creepy monsters come.. When you're nearly dying of hungry and slowly start to go insane. That is when things start to get creepy! Where did that music come from!? Stay off my campfire! Oh no, My torch just ran out.....

The art is simple but appealing, reminds me of Tim Burton a bit. The characters speak an amusing jibberish, and all of them have great up- and downsides depending on your playstyle.

This game may cause some rage-quits, but it is very rewarding to stay alive! .. My Rage quit: . After i set my own farm on fire by accident with a very nervous Willow (character, who loves fire a tad too much) my hp started to drop because i was starving without my crops. A few minutes later 3 hounds came and ate me. Damnit! Mother of all ragequits.. And yet i started to play again within a day. It's just so appealing. The Reign of Giants DLC is fun, but not my cup-o-tea. I prefer the normal version. But it is fun to mix and match up at times, i would still recommend atleast trying it.

reviewText:
This is my favorite survival game ever. Even if you're not into the 2D graphics the gameplay is super easy to get started with but really tough to master making it *IMO* very fun. Everytime you play you'll have a slightly different expirience as the world" is randomly generated so there's a lot of replay value here.

When you're getting started the base game should be enough but once you have mastered winter you'll need to upgrade to the "Reign of Giants" DLC.

9/10

PS: If you're having a hard time mastering the "kiting" technique and want an easy way to get started play as WX-78 and increase the number of clockwork robots in the customizeable world settings. The gears they drop will keep you going until you've got a decent base and having to kite them will teach you a lot quickly."

reviewText: Two hours in and I am completely hooked on this seemingly silly little game. I did not expect the mechanics and setting to be so immersive but they stand up strong next to any 3D" games that can be found in this genre. When night falls I feel a genuine sense of peril and urgency to get back to my camp or risk death by any one of a variety of night-time creepies. Thats hard to pull of in a cartoony 2D game. Im not a huge horror fan
date: but this game has juuuuuuuust the right amount of suspense to make it exciting but not nerve-wrackingly scary. On that point - the graphics are fantastic for what they are meant to be
recommended: a dark comedic romp through a 2D survival sim that seems to be something out of a Tim Burton movie. My only small issue is the controller option is a tiny bit hard to use for construction on your site. Its hard to get things in the right spot to place
hoursPlayed: making it frustrating when building your shelter. Otherwise fantastic so far :) 9/10"

reviewText:
For what I played in the demo only, I could say it is totally my type of game of survival and environemental survival so far.  I hate not having had enough time with it...  :)  But I guess it was the whole deal with a full week-end (if ever I would had stayed home longer ;) ).

Usually I flee demon related games within the exception of Diablo.  But this one so far in my full hour deserved all the attention I could put in it.  No tutorial but all too intuitive you end-up well immersed too.

EDIT 24th May 2015
I finally have the game and found the portal to stage 2 a couples of time.  No matter how long my game last (Normally now between 15 to 27 days in-game), I still marvel at discovering new things and tricks and I don't want to apply yet mods to fully discover this world and new strategies and how to pass winter.

I don't think I can ever being bored with it.  Just having some things more urgent to do IRL than quench my need to survival or quench my need to prove my ingenuity.  But yet I never yet seen the like!  It is fun, yet intuitive and just enough realism to see all seasons for a crafty enough player.  ;)

What can I say about Don't Starve?

The game has changed so much since it's early access stages that it's like playing a different game in a good way.

It's probably one of the best sandbox adventure game out in the market, with a huge and I say HUGE content from both the devs and all the modding community.

Buy the Alone pack for all the dlc, or get the Mega Pack for the online experience with friends, either way you'll get hundreds of hours of pure entertainment.

reviewText:
Simply Fantastic.  Can't say I've seen anything like it in all my gaming years (over 20  years now).
In a class of its own, despite being a survival game.
When I saw the game in the Steam store, I watched the videos, read some reviews, then checked out the community and workshop.  The art direction of this series has always intrigued me, I just wasn't sure if it was something I could get in to.
The game went on Sale this week, so I picked it up.  It's safe to say, 'the rest is history'.

What an amazing little survival game!  I literally have to watch myself with this one, because what seems like 15-20min ends up being an hour or two, without even batting an eye about it.  The sounds, music, mechanics, map design, 'critter' art and designs, all of it are just superb, and unique.

The game runs flawlessly, without any hiccups, so far.  The modding community for this game is alive and well, ensuring that this series won't be going away anytime soon.

I highly recommend this game to ANY kind of gamer, it will surprise you!  I haven't really played the Together" version yet
date: but I'm quite certain it will only add even more fun to the game
hoursPlayed: some hillarious moments!\n\n5/5 Stars for this one.  Buy it.  Play it.  I'm not responsible for any addiction that occurs there-after.  ;)"

reviewText:
This is a wilderness survival sandbox featuring lovecraftian horrors pig men jackalopes and other strange things. You start in a sandbox mode shanghied by the mysterious maxwell and can work through an adventure mode within the sandbox.

You have 3 stat bars health hunger and sanity controling these stats is the key to surviving as long as possible. You build prototypes of new equipment and structures to advance in the game and increase your probability of long term survival.

This is not another minecraft clone and is an awsome game despite lack of multiplayer. Hunting gathering trapping beekeeping crafting fishing herding, all possibilities in this immersive game. Overall definatley worth the price if you like sandbox games and survivalism in general intruiges you, give this game a try.

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3uQsDus53AE

Don’t Starve & Don’t Starve Together: Don’t Starve & its multiplayer component, Don’t Starve Together, is an indie sandbox survival game of the weird & mysterious variety. Developed & published by Klei Entertainment. The gameplay is simple which is pretty common for Klei, the controls are nothing special which isn’t bad, the gameplay itself is mostly fun although I have some personal gripes with combat.

But, first, let’s talk about the graphics, the game is an isometric 2.5D game, with this really intriguing dark pencil drawn art style, the fact that the world of Don’t Starve itself is this mysterious & weird world also lends itself to this type of art style. The music also reminds me of this sort of twisted carnival feel, with lots of weird strings & brass instruments used to set the tone, characters also speak with mashed up music tones from different instruments, sounding mostly unpleasant.

So as it’s about survival, you’ll brave all the elements of the seasons, the ever present drain on your sanity & your belly grumbling. Don’t Starve also features plenty of dangerous creatures as well as some neutral ones ranging from the Pigmen to the aggressive fish like Merms & of course with the Reign of Giants DLC, Giant boss monsters like the Deerclops. It’s a pretty challenging game, don’t expect to survive very long with your first forays into Don’t Starve, you’ll die plenty of times but, never unfairly so, as you learn the game you will become a better survivor & the game rewards you for how long you survive by unlock more characters to play with a total of eleven to choose from all with their own strengths & weaknesses. The story of Don’t Starve is only accessible through the sandbox mode which you start in, if you wish to know how to get there, you’ll have to experiment to find out.

My only real gripe is with the games ‘combat’, you interact with the world mainly with the mouse, you can hold the spacebar to pick up nearby objects which is really handy, you can use the mouse or keyboard to move around, but, when in combat, I only ever was able to use the mouse, this is a problem, since the world is flat it is very easy & common for things to get in the way. This is only exasperated when things are hectic, it’s very annoying when there is multiple enemies. There are several ways to avoid combat, but, when you must it’s a pain dealing with multiple enemies at once. Other than that gripe the game is just pure fun, the multiplayer part was so simple to setup I can’t find anything to complain about, it’s the whole single player game with friends up to six & it’s easy to use plus you get two copies for the one price so it’s pretty cheap.

I personally love Don’t Starve, it was a bit to get into at first, mostly because I was failing a lot at the beginning, but, once I gave it a serious shot I began to get better & better & could survive a very long time before dying, if you like survival type games in general definitely check this out, if you don’t like a challenge, or don’t like indies (for some reason) or just don’t like things that aren’t 3D ultra-graphics & “realistic” then steer clear of the quirky world of Don’t Starve, for the rest, we’ll be trying to survive despite the odds. Its $14.99 USD which is a pretty good deal, I’d recommend getting the bundle with the Reign of Giants for $18.99 USD which will give you a ton of stuff, or get the bundle that comes with a copy of Don’t Starve Together which includes the Reign of Giants DLC & bring a friend along for the ride! Thank you Klei Entertainment for awesome deals on awesome games!

TL/DR; Don’t Starve is a wonderful survival game that doesn’t take itself too seriously but does offer a serious challenge for new comers. It’s got a very unique art style. The game is simple to play & simple to run with the sandbox goal of ‘survive’, it holds no hands & still expects you to succeed, it’s a fun game, & its multiplayer component Don’t Starve Together makes the experience even better with the ability to bring friends along for the suffering. I highly recommend check out both titles, they offer good deals for the single & multiplayer experience, unless you can’t stand the look of the game, or need that “realistic” approach to survival then check out Don’t Starve & Don’t Starve Together!

-Double Thumbs Up from Royial

reviewText:
Almost 40 hours into the game and I've only scratched the surface. I have just managed to survive the winter with some ease but I haven't even tried the adventure mode nor gone into any caves nor hunted the Koalephant nor fought the walrus or any of those chess-inspired-geared-thingies... meaning that I have yet to explore more than half of what Don't Starve has to offer.

I can't wait to experience the rest of it and maybe someday even try out the terrifying-sounding DLC Reign of Giants....or at least gain some experience so I'll be a good partner in Don't Starve Together.

The game is worth definitely every euro (or dollar) it costs. It has a vast, beautiful, intricate and carefully built world with interesting mechanics and adorable sounds!

reviewText: Dont starve is one of those games that every time you play you get a little better at it and in doing so you feel an overall feeling of acheivement not seen in many games (dare i say it,it reminded me of the feeling i had playing dark souls).Very much like the classic games from FROM SOFTWARE this game throws you in at the deep end and you either sink or swim,having said that every time you die when you play next time you know a little bit more to get that little bit further and survive for that little bit longer.I have many a time played this game and yet i seem to keep being surprised by the amount of new things i keep bumping into (especially during a full moon OH THAT WAS CREEPY).I love the games that the developers made before this one (the shank games are fantastic-still remind me of the film machete though) but i think that this game is their crowning glory and will be hard for them to top.The graphics suit this game and just add to the overall experience you have whilst playing.Again this is another game that again shows up the big developers and shows that smaller developers have more more orriginality than they do (money does'nt allways mean that your game is the best and shiny graphice dont allways make good gameplay please take note all you power hungry developers).In closing i love this game and if you want a challenge you should look no further than DONT STARVE.

reviewText: Wonderful. Simple. Brilliant. Entertaining. Don't Starve is a terrifically stylish survivaly sim with a wicked since of humor and mechanics that even the lowly exclusive FarmVille player can adapt to and understand.
